data.text: Contents
Introduction

The aim of this policy is to provide guidance for Registered Nurses (RN) (NMC) actively involved in the authorisation of red blood cells and platelets for transfusion, for patients on a long term regular transfusion regime.
This policy has been written for Mid Essex (Broomfield) Registered Nurses to meet the standards required by:
EU Blood Directive 2002/98/EC monitored by the Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency (MHRA).
The competencies required by the National Patient Safety Agency (NPSA).
Guidelines from the British Committee Standards for Haematology (BSH, previously BCSH).
Scope

The scope of the document is to provide information for all appropriate MSE Mid Essex Trust staff regarding adult haematology patients requiring a transfusion of red blood cells (RBC) or platelets as out-patient's, in the Day IV Therapies department.

It applies to Registered Nurses (RN's) who have completed the Non-Medical Authorisation of Blood course, or Independent Nurse Prescribing Programme and deemed competent by the Consultant Haematologist, see section 4.5 for futher information.

The Mid Essex Hospital Transfusion Group (HTG) meets to co-ordinate the varying interests of all parties involved in the transfusion policies and procedures to ensure the safe and appropriate use of these products.

Section 130 of the 1968 Medicines Act and amended by the Section  of the Blood Safety and Quality Regulations 2005 (SI 2005). Blood and Blood Components (Red Cells, Platelets, Fresh Frozen Plasma and Cryoprecipitate) are excluded from a legal definition of medicinal products and therefore cannot be “prescribed” by any practitioner. The usual terminology is therefore authorisation of blood products. However, in this policy the authorisation of blood may be referred to as the prescription.
Definitions

table_items.text: Meet to co-ordinate the varying interests of all parties involved in the transfusion policies and procedures to ensure the safe and appropriate use of products.
The prescriber of a blood component
Registered Nurse practicing under the NMC

data.text: Roles and responsibilities
Role and responsibilities within the MSE Mid Essex Trust (Committees) Duties Are:
Committee 1 – Delegation – Mid Essex Hospital Transfusion Group (HTG).
Committee 2 – MSE Quality Governance Group.
Role and responsibilities of Individuals within the MSE Trust Mid Essex Duties Are:
Role 1 – Mid Essex Consultant Haematologist - the delegator.
Role 2 – Mid Essex RN authoriser of blood components - the delegate.
Delegation
The Delegator
The Delegator will be the Consultant Haematologist in charge of the patient and will be responsible for the care and treatment of an individual patient.
The patient must have a care plan in place documenting diagnosis, current treatment, thresholds and targets for transfusion.

The delegator will continue to be responsible for drawing up a clear plan of treatment for patients requiring transfusion of blood or platelets and for annual review or as required following transfusion reaction.
The Delegate The authoriser will:
Be a first level registered nurse (RN), working at Mid Essex.
Have a relevant first degree or equivalent in terms of prior learning at the appropriate level.
Have attended either the non-medical authorisation of blood course or the Independent Nurse Prescribing course and have the support of the Consultant Haematologist.
Must have the support of their line manager and clinical consultant.
Must have at least three years post registration experience.
Have at least one year working as RN immediately preceding within the relevant clinical specialty.
Manage a caseload of patients or work as part of a clinical team managing patients' needs.
Demonstrate competence according to the knowledge assessment documents.
The RN will be responsible for obtaining adequate knowledge and
experience.

The RN will be working in the field where they are authorising components,  e.g. if they move to a different area of the Hospital from where they were  assessed they will not be entitled to authorise blood components.

data.url: 14011 Authorisation of allogenic blood and platelets 3.0.003.png

data.text: The RN is accountable for their actions and omissions in practice and must always be able to justify decisions regardless of advice or directions from other professionals.
The RN will identify a Consultant Haematologist who has agreed to act as a mentor and assessor.
Ensure that ongoing follow up of the patient is in place.
Responsibilities
The Mid Essex Consultant Haematologist will:

Ensure that the Registered Nurse (RN) allowed to authorise red blood cells and platelets, will have completed the mandatory blood transfusion training  within Mid Essex within the preceding two-year period.

data.url: 14011 Authorisation of allogenic blood and platelets 3.0.004.png

data.text: Be responsible for the blood/platelet transfusion.
Ensure that the RN has completed the Knowledge Assessment – Blood Product Authorisation (see appendix 1).
Ensure the RN has completed the appropriate blood transfusion competencies for their role, these competencies are to be completed and passed every three years:
The Registered Nurse (RN) authoriser must:
Complete the Nurse Knowledge Assessment: Blood Product Authorisation (see appendix 1), every three years.
Demonstrate competence according to the MSE Trust Blood Transfusion competency documents every three years (see the Manual of Blood Transfusion Policies and Procedures policy).
Authorise blood and platelets at least twelve times per year.
Be responsible for obtaining adequate knowledge and experience to enable them to complete the competency assessment.
Identify a Haematology Consultant as mentor and assessor.
Interpret blood results and understand that the written instruction should
include:
Identify and discuss the incompatibility of blood with other infusion fluids/IV drugs.
Have knowledge of anatomy and physiology of blood products and understand the structure, growth and function of red cells, white cells, platelets and plasma.
Have an understanding of anaemia, and:
Must be aware of the pre transfusion testing process:
Must know the indications for the use of blood components:
required.
Must know the special transfusion requirements that may be needed:
Must know the risks and adverse events associated with transfusion and how to deal with them.
Understand the risks of transfusion and describe what to do in an emergency situation.
Demonstrates knowledge of the MSE Mid Essex Trust Transfusion Protocol and the sections relevant to them.
Aware of the patient information leaflets that are available.
Know their legal responsibilities in regard to record keeping and that the reason for the transfusion should be documented in the patient's notes and discharge summaries to the GP.

Has knowledge and understanding of the NMC July 2009 record Keeping Guidance for nurses and midwives and the NMC March 2015, The Code: Professional standards and Practice and behaviour for nurses and midwives.
Can explain why the reason for transfusion should be recorded in the patient notes.
Can explain why all actions and omissions must be and are documented.
Will ensure that when ordering blood or platelets, they have knowledge of local guidelines for ordering of these blood components and be aware that the laboratory requires the following details:
Knows the administration process:
Procedure for Obtaining and Authorising Blood Products
Written Request
Request forms must be completed in full with all relevant clinical information, special requirement and transfusion details as per the MSE Trust Manual of Blood Transfusion Policies and Procedures.
The requesting RGN must clearly print his/her name with their contact details on and sign the request form.
Verbal Request
Verbal requests may only be made when there is a current valid transfusion sample in the Mid Essex Blood Transfusion Laboratory.
All verbal requests must be made stating the patient's identity as a minimum:
First name
Last name
Date of birth
NHS Number
The patient's hospital number
Gender

The authorising Registered Nurse (RN) should ensure that the transfusion charts are completed. The patient must be clearly identified with a wristband/identification by full name, DOB, hospital number, gender and/or NHS number.
Any special requirements such as (but not limited to) irradiated blood/blood products, and Cytomegalovirus (CMV) negative blood products and known antibodies should be documented.
The Registered Nurse (RN) authorising the blood component, should ensure that all medications required are prescribed (e.g. furosemide, paracetamol, chlorephenamine, hydrocortisone) as appropriate.

The Registered Nurse (RN) authorising the blood component should decide on the number of units required. For adult patients one unit of blood would be expected to raise the Hb by approximately  g/l, if the patient weighs 70kg.
The route of administration should be documented including number of units to be transfused and duration of each unit.

The duration of transfusion of the unit will be, for red blood cells, 2-3hours per unit 150mls per hour (completed within a maximum of 4 hours from removal from the blood bank) or as specified by the Haematology Consultant/Consultant in charge of the patient and platelets 20-30mins per adult therapeutic dose or as specified by the Haematology Consultant in charge of the patient.

All requests for platelets should be discussed with a Consultant Haematologist in the first instance. In the majority of cases, one unit of platelets will be adequate and is expected to raise the platelet count by approximately  x /l. The RN would
need to escalate to the Consultant Haematologist if the increment was not as expected from the transfusion as the patient may become refractory to platelets.
The RN will ensure the patient is aware what action they should take and who to contact in the event that the patient feels unwell following discharge after the transfusion episode.
Adverse Events
Any adverse event must be documented – see the MSE Manual of Blood Transfusion Policies and Procedures policy.
Nursing staff caring for the patient should report a transfusion reaction immediately to the Doctor in charge, and must then inform the Blood Transfusion Department .
The RN needs to have completed the MSE Trust's appropriate Basic Life Support training course and be able to deal with a suspected transfusion reaction. It is
expected that the RN authorising would have training in dealing with anaphylactic reactions, and be able to administer medications as appropriate to the
reaction e.g. paracetamol, hydrocortisone, antihistamine, and/or adrenaline.
The clinician must complete, in full, a Transfusion Reaction Form and send the form together with a the post transfusion samples to the Blood Transfusion Department.
The donor unit must be returned with the transfusion reaction form. If the giving set is still inserted into the donor unit, this must also be returned to the laboratory intact.
The Clinician or RN needs to ensure the following bloods are returned to the Mid Essex Blood Transfusion Department for suspected transfusion reaction
investigation:
- Post transfusion Group and Save sample
- Post transfusion sample for Full Blood Count and clotting screen
- Post transfusion sample for U&E, LFT and LDH
- Post transfusion sample Haptoglobin levels
- First urine voided post reaction
Blood Transfusion Reaction Reporting Forms are available from the Blood Transfusion Department and on the Mid Essex Trust Intranet.
A risk event form must be completed with the details of the pre transfusion vital
signs, the vital signs at the time of the reaction and details of any medications
given, and the time the patients vital signs return to baseline. This should then be forwarded to the Transfusion Practitioner to complete with the results of the
Laboratory investigations and will be reported to SHOT/SABRE if required.
Other adverse events such as (but not limited to):
the blood product not being given or authorised over the correct period of time (out of the 4 hour timeframe allowed from blood bank to completion)
inappropriate transfusion given (the patient did not require the product authorised)
a unit of RBC or platelets not administered with the correct giving set.
Training requirements
The Nurse authoriser must be a first level registered nurse (RN)
Have a relevant first degree or equivalent in terms of prior learning at the appropriate level.

Have attended either the Non-Medical Authorisation (NMA) of blood course or the Independent Nurse Prescribing course. If the RN has only completed the Nurse Prescribing course, the RN must be a Haematology Nurse Specialist, working in the field of Haematology and have the support of the Consultant Haematologist to undertake authorization (prescribing) of RBC and Platelets.
Have completed the MSE Trust's mandatory blood transfusion training within the last two years.
Completed the attached nurse competency assessment appendix 1.
Completed and passed the appropriate competency assessments for:
Monitoring and audit
A review of transfusions authorised by the Registered Nurse (RN) will be carried
out by the Haematology Consultant managing the patient, after the initial 6 months from starting to write authorisations, then yearly afterwards.
The questions the audit will aim to answer will include:
Did the patient have a clear plan of treatment drawn up by the Consultant Haematologist?
Did the patient have a current haemoglobin or platelet result recorded prior to the transfusion?
If an adverse event is noted during this episode, was this documented in the patient's notes and reported?
The aim of the audit is to ensure the correct authorisation of blood products by the RN authorising blood and platelets.

Audit results that do not meet the correct process, will be reported to the Mid Essex Consultant Haematologist, the Mid Essex Hospital Transfusion Team (HTT), the MSE Mid Essex Hospital Transfusion Group (HTG) and to the MSE Quality Governance Group.

The authorisation of RBC and platelets by RN's

MSE Mid Essex Hospital Transfusion Group

data.text: Approval and implementation
All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the MSE Mid Essex
Hospital Transfusion Group, which is the specialist group with the authority to
approve local pathology blood and platelet guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the MSE Mid Essex Hospital Transfusion Group of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranet site.
References

Assessment will be through a question and answer session covering the following:
